metadata.title: Microstructure and mechanical properties of in-situ nano -Al2O3p/A356 aluminum matrix composite

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Alloys and Compounds
journal homepage: http: / /www.elsevier .com/locate/ ja lcom
Microstructure and mechanical properties of in-situ nano g-Al2O3p/ A356 aluminum matrix composite
Tuo Xu, Guirong Li*, Menglei Xie, Ming Liu, De Zhang, Yutao Zhao, Gang Chen, Xizhou Kai School of Materials Science & Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 December 2018 Received in revised form 4 February 2019 Accepted 4 February 2019 Available online 6 February 2019
Keywords: Nano g-Al2O3p/A356 composites Microstructure Si modification Grain refinement Homogeneous distribution Tensile properties
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: liguirong@ujs.edu.cn (G. Li).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2019.02.045 0925-8388/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
In this study, the nanometer in-situ g-Al2O3 particles reinforced aluminum matrix composites was successfully fabricated by the A356 aluminum alloy and Co3O4 powder at 850 C by means of in-situ reaction in the high temperature melt. The effects of g-Al2O3 particle and cobalt element on the microstructure and properties of the composites were investigated in detail. The endogenous g-Al2O3 and cobalt could modify the coarse plate like eutectic Si into fine fibrous like and refine the second dendrite arm spacing (SDAS) of the grains simultaneously. When the content of cobalt was lower than 0.57% and content of g-Al2O3particles was lower than 0.6 vol%, the particles distributed uniformly in the grain, however, when the particulate amount was up to 0.8 vol%, the particles would distribute at the grains boundaries or form as a rodlike phase. The grain size was sharply refined to 200 mm when the particulate content was 0.8 vol%. It was found that the ultimate tensile strength (UTS), elongation of the 0.6 vol% g-Al2O3/A356 composites had arrived at the maximum that had enhanced by 43.6% and 85.7% in comparison to the matrix respectively, which were attributed to the homogeneous distribution of the nanoparticles, the refinement of the SDAS of the a-Al grains and the modification of the eutectic Si phases.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the beginning of the 21st century, people have started to pay attention to the automobile lightweight, due to the critical problems as climate change and energy crisis. Usage of MMCs(Metal matrix composites), such as aluminum alloy composites and magnesium alloy matrix composites, has been enormously increasing because of its high strength to weight ratio, light density and high specific stiffness [1e4]. In comparison to the pure metal and alloy, MMCs possess a higher strength to weight ratio, wear resistance, lower shrinkage, lower coefficient of thermal expansion, enhanced mechanical and thermal properties [5e9]. MMCs have become really attractive for automotive and aerospace applications. The particle form reinforcement presents in the composites exhibits an isotropic property when compared with other geometries of reinforcement such as fiber and whisker. Fiber and whisker composites are generally anisotropic. Besides this, the advantages of particulate composites further include mechanical
strength improvement, operating temperature increase, oxidation resistance enhancement, easy production and so on [10e12].
In conventional fabrication processes of AMCs (Aluminum Matrix Composites), the reinforcements have been added in the two modes of external or in-situ and formed as ex-situ or in-situ composites. A variety of hard ceramic particles have been introduced to be the reinforcements, such as SiC [13], TiC [14], ZrB2 [4,7e10,15], TiB2 [16], AlN [17] and Al2O3 [3,8e23], some of which also can act as the nucleating sites for grain refinement, and as the propeller in strength, hardness, and wear resistance [12]. These reinforcements have exhibited several classic characteristics as high melting points, high hardness, high modulus of elasticity, and low coefficient of thermal expansion.
As for the efficiency and productivity of the ex/in situ methods, there are some defects and difficulties to fabricate composites by ex-situ methods. For example, the particulate morphology, is difficult to be controlled at nanoscale, the fine particles are difficult to add, the interfacial reactions are likely to occur between the reinforcement and the matrix during the fabrication process [23]. The weak matrix/reinforcement interface, inhomogeneous distribution of reinforcement particles, low wettability between particle and matrix, in most cases, make a deadly effect on material
properties. In the in-situ process, the reinforcement phases are formed in metallic matrix through the salt reaction or oxidationreduction reaction between the additive particles and matrix during composite fabrication process. There are many advantages for AMCs synthesized by in-situ process. For example, the in-situ formed reinforcements are thermodynamically stable, free of surface contamination and homogeneous distribution in matrix and strong particleematrix bonding.
For aluminum matrix composites, the problem of reinforced particles agglomeration has always existed since the invention of composite and is difficult to be solved. The agglomeration phenomenon is affected by many factors. The most important factors are the particulate sizes and the wettability of the interface between the particles and thematrix.When the particulate size is less than eighty percent of critical radius, the particle can be engulfed by the grain during the solidification process [24]. The approaches to improving the wettability included: (i) increasing the surface energies of the solids, (ii) decreasing the surface tension of the liquid matrix alloy, and (iii) decreasing the solid/liquid interfacial energy [24]. Till to now, Mg element can decrease the Al alloy surface tension and the effect of Si element is not as effective as Mg [25]. Therefore, A356 was selected as the matrix alloy in this study because of its components.
In the previous study, it was found that many metallic oxides CuO, SnO2, ZnO, Cr2O3 had been used for producing Al2O3 [26]. They found that in order to produce adequate Al2O3 the metal produced frequently exceeded the dissolution limit of the metal in aluminum [20]. Thus superfluous amount of intermetallic compounds such as CuAl2 will form in matrix. Intermetallic compounds are brittle phrase, which often result in the decline of mechanical properties. Most of the metal oxides can react with aluminum by means of oxidation-reduction reaction, but Co3O4 is hopeful to affect the morphology of silicon after being reduced. Therefore, in this study A356 and Co3O4 were selected as raw materials to investigate the synergistic effect of in-situ g-Al2O3 and cobalt element on the microstructure and mechanical properties of A356 alloy.
A356 is a hypoeutectic aluminum alloy, consisting of plate-like eutectic silicon and a-aluminum dendrite. With trace additions of certain chemical modifiers, like Na and Sr, the eutectic Si phase can be refined from coarse plate-like to fine fibrous [27]. The morphological change of Si, which is induced by impurity atom modification, can make an improvement of the mechanical properties of AleSi alloys. S. Lu implied many elements had similar functions as sodium and strontium [28]. Eu [29] and Sc [30] have been proved to be effective modifier, however, others have not been researched, for example cobalt. Layer growth [28] and twin plane re-entrant edge (TPRE) growth [31] are the two postulations, which have been widely accepted by publication, of the growth model of eutectic Si. For the layer growth, the driving force is entropy of fusion per atom [28]. For the twin plane re-entrant edge (TPRE) growth, the re-entrant corners are consisted of the {111} twin planes intersect surfaces of silicon phase [32]. Atoms attach preferentially to the kink sites of steps in layer growth and re-entrant corners in TPRE growth [33]. Therefore, both of the two models can explain the morphology of Si phase. Si crystals grow preferentially in<110> directions, and present anisotropy.
There are two main mechanisms of chemical modification eutectic Si phase in AleSi alloys which are widely accepted. In the AleSi alloys without modifier added condition, there are three possible sites for Si phase to nucleate [34]. Almost all of commercial cast aluminum alloys contain the Fe element more or less, the Fe can form intermetallic b-Al5FeSi with aluminum and silicon during solidification [35]. This is the first site that can be the nucleation site of Si phase. In the former researches, some foundry added phosphorus reacted with aluminum form AlP, which was the second site
for Si phase nucleation [36]. During the smelting process, aluminum melt sucked the oxygen in the air to react to form an oxide film. The oxide films presented in front of the solidifying Al dendrites was regarded as the third site that Si may nucleate [37]. For b-Al5FeSi phase, regarding as the Si nucleation site, the addition of Sr can decrease the forming temperature of b-Al5FeSi phase and Al-Si phase, result in a significant undercooling of the interdendritic liquid compare with the eutectic temperature [36,38]. The eutectic phase presents a refined morphology. For the AlP phase, after the addition of Sr, they will react with Al and Si to form Al2Si2Sr which precipitates on the pre-existing AlP compound, result in a condition of that the nucleate site of Si phase decrease, forcing the eutectic Si to nucleate at larger undercooling [36]. Sr and Na can react with P by forming Sr3P/Na3P [38,39]. The effect of Sr/Na addition on the two nucleation sites belongs to the constitutional undercooling mechanism.
For the layer growth model, the large impurity atoms displace {111} monolayer atoms to the change the Si atoms stacking sequence to form Si twins. This twin generation mechanism by introducing impurity atoms is named impurity-induced twinning (IIT) mechanism [40]. For the TPRE mechanism, with sodium or strontium addition, Sr/Na atoms concentrate at the re-entrant edges, which remove the growth advantage of the TPRE mechanism, the anisotropic growth habit of silicon on specific crystallographic planes is reduced as well [41]. A recent research by electron back-scattered diffraction(EBSD) revealed that the TPRE growth in unmodified AleSi alloys was on the <110> direction, and the exposure of Si-{111} planes to the melt to reduce interfacial energy. The microscopic <011ð Þ>growth direction is realized by a paired <112ð Þ> zigzag growth at atomic scale [42].
The present paper is to fabricate in-situ Al2O3 particlereinforced aluminum matrix composites and investigates the effect of in-situ g-Al2O3 particles and reduced cobalt on the microstructure and mechanical properties of A356 alloy.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental procedure
sections.text:
A356 aluminum alloy ingot was used as matrix material and cobalt (II, III) oxide was employed to react with aluminum to produce in-situ Al2O3 particles as reinforcement. Table 1 showed the chemical composition of the above-mentioned raw materials. The cobalt (II, III) oxide powder was preheated to dehydrate and improve activity in tube furnace at 800 C for 1 h. The A356 ingot was melt at 750 C and held for 10min in a clay-bonded graphite crucible under argon atmosphere in an electrical resistance furnace. Then the melt was degassed by commercial degasser hexachloroethane (C2Cl6) and the extra slag was skimmed from the melt. Subsequently, the melt was cooled to 600 C. On this condition the melt would be transformed from liquid to semisolid state, and kept furnace temperature comparatively invariant. At the same time, the trefoil shape mechanical paddle was used to generate a vortex at a speed 800 rpm (rounds per minute) and argon gas was supplied into the crucible at a constant flow rate of 2 lpm (liters per minute) to avoid the possible reaction of matrix with the atmospheric air. The surface of the paddle was covered by commercial coating agent that could reduce the solution of stainless paddle. The Co3O4 powder was added into the vortex at a constant speed. The stirring
and adding powder time was designed as 10min. The amount of insitu g-Al2O3 particles that came from direct oxidation-reduction reaction by Co3O4 and aluminum was 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 vol%, and 0.8 vol%, respectively. Then the temperature of semisolid aluminum was heated up and held as 850 C for 1 h to ensure the reaction to carry out completely. Subsequently, the melt was cooled to 720 C. After the slag on the surface of the melt was skimmed, the melt was poured into a preheated about 200 C steel mold. Being as protective gas, the argon gas was supplied continuously until the entire melt was poured into a permanent mold.
Scanning ElectronMicroscope (SEM, FEI NovaNano450, HITACHI 3400n, JSM 7800F) and incidental Electronic Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy(EDX) were employed to observe the morphology of matrix, distribution state, sizes and amount of reinforcement phases. Each composites sample with certain content was divided two parts: one was subjected to the T4 heat treatment as 540 C for 3 h solution, cold water quenching. SEM specimens were prepared according to the normative metallographic procedures, which were etched using 5%HF. The size of tensile specimenwas shown in Fig. 1 and the tensile test was processed on the basis of ASTM standard.
The ultimate tensile strength (UTS) was estimated using a computer-controlled electronic tensile testing machine, and its average values of three samples were recorded. Fracture surfaces of the tensile specimens were further examined by SEM in order to evaluate the fracture mechanisms.

sections.heading: 3.1. Silicon phase in g- Al2O3p/A356 composite
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of as-cast A356 alloy matrix and composite with different content of in-situ g-Al2O3 particles.
The microstructure of A365 alloy without Co3O4 powder addition is composed of a-Al and eutectic Si, as shown in Fig. 2a. For the A356 alloy, the coarse dendritic a-Al grains that are surrounded by the coarse acicular eutectic Si particles will greatly deteriorate the mechanical properties. The secondary dendrite arm space (SDAS) of a-Al dendrites is about 33 mm. Fig. 2b shows the microstructure of A356 alloy containing 0.2 vol% in-situ g-Al2O3 particle. In comparison to the Fig. 2a, the SDAS of a-Al dendrites has decreased sharply to about 22 mm that is only almost 2/3 of the former. Fig. 2c and d present the microstructure of in-situ 0.4 vol% and 0.6 vol% gAl2O3 reinforced A356 composites whose SDAS are 16e18 mm and 13e14 mm separately. As for Fig. 2e of 0.8 vol% in-situ g-Al2O3, the boundaries between a-Al and eutectic Si are not as clear as Fig. 2bed. Meanwhile, the SDAS has augmented to 25e30 mm,
besides some of a-Al dendrites present the tendency of columnar grain and coarsening. As for the volume fraction of a-Al dendrites, it presents the tendency as first increase along Fig. 2a/Fig. 2b/ Fig. 2c/Fig. 2d and decrease along Fig. 2d/Fig. 2e.
In order to investigate the effect of in-situ endogenous g-Al2O3 particles on the matrix morphology including eutectic Si and a-Al dendrites, the microstructure was further characterized by SEM, as shown in Fig. 3. It is obviously observed that the eutectic Si of the unmodified A356 alloy shows relatively coarse and exhibits flakelike structure with sharp edges. The maximum length of Si phase is 80 mm as shown Fig. 3a. The length of flake-like Si decreases gradually from Fig. 3aed with the increase of volume fraction of gAl2O3. The maximum Si phase lengths of 0.2,0.4,0.6 vol% g-Al2O3p/ A356 samples are 55 mm, 24 mm and 19 mm respectively. However, a portion of eutectic Si phases present a coarsening tendency in 0.8 vol% g-Al2O3p/A356 sample and the maximum length of flakelike Si has enhanced to 50 mm. Beyond above, the a-Al dendrite has been substituted by the equiaxed grains and columnar grain. Moreover, the sharp edges of eutectic silicon become smoother with the increase of g-Al2O3 proportion. Therefore, the stress concentration is hopeful to be reduced at the tip of eutectic silicon due to the length decrease and width increase of eutectic silicon. The morphology of eutectic silicon has changed from long needlelike to short plate-like and particulate structure. It can be, therefore, concluded that g-Al2O3 can not only reduce the SDAS of a-Al dendrites, but the eutectic silicon morphology can be modified at the same time during the process of solidification. On the basis of current experimental results, the optimum proportion of g-Al2O3 is confirmed as 0.6 vol%.
With regard to the distribution of g-Al2O3 in the A356 matrix with different amount, the microstructure characteristic can be found in Fig. 4.In Fig. 4a and b, the distribution of g-Al2O3 particles is uniform, and the size of most g-Al2O3 particles is below 100 nm and exhibits as spherical shape. The g-Al2O3 particles can be found not only in the a-Al matrix but the interfaces between matrix and silicon, some on the surface of eutectic silicon. In the Fig. 4c and d, it manifests that with the content increase of g-Al2O3 particles, the distribution state of g-Al2O3 particles is not as uniform as that of 0.6 vol% g-Al2O3p/A356 composite sample. The particles present the morphology as small aggregation and floccule. The amount of g-Al2O3 particles in the grain is fewer than 0.6 vol% and it is the same with the internals of a-Al dendrite and the interface of Al/Si.
3.2. Element distribution in g-Al2O3p/A356 composites
Fig. 5 shows the elements map of 0.6%vol% g-Al2O3p/A356
the tensile specimen.
composite that is detected by SEM Energy Dispersive X-ray Detector. The magnesium element distributes uniformly in the matrix rather than consistent with oxygen element, indicating no spinel formation. As shown in Fig. 5e, the distribution of oxygen element is almost uniform, only a little proportion of oxygen element aggregation in the Co phases. The distribution trend of cobalt element (Fig. 5f) is similar with oxygen element but the distribution is not completely consistent and there is no large size cobalt and aluminum intermetallic compound.
3.3. Grain size and orientation of g-Al2O3p/A356 composite
Fig. 6 presents the electron back scattered diffraction (EBSD) OIM image, which demonstrates the orientation and crystalline dimension. It manifests that the changing trend of grain size is mild from Fig. 6aed, which is accompanied by the different content of g-
Al2O3 particles. According to EBSD software calculation, the maximum grain size of the A356 g-Al2O3 free is around 1790 mm. With the g-Al2O3 content increase, the maximum grain size of 0.2%, 0.4%, 0.6% and 0.8% g-Al2O3 content composites are 1640 mm, 1100 mm, 1460 mm and 625 mm respectively. The A356 alloy and its composites are in the as-cast state, so the grain orientation of aluminum alloy shows the characteristic of isotropy.

sections.heading: 3.4. Microstructural characterization of Al2O3p/A356 composite by TEM
sections.text:
The particulate dispersion in the 0.6 vol% g-Al2O3p/A356 composite is further investigated by TEM. There are plenty of dislocations and nano g-Al2O3 particles around the Al9Co2 submicron phase. It is extrapolated that both of the two kinds of particles take the effects to pin the dislocations. There is no contamination exist
at the interface between the g-Al2O3 particles with the Al matrix nor the interface of Al9Co2 with Al matrix. The clean interface between the matrix with reinforcement particles is beneficial to enhance the capabilities of corrosion resistance and high temperature strength.
Fig. 7b shows a Al9Co2 particle, whose dimension is under 1 mm, grows on the grain boundary. Half interface of the particle is coincidence with the grain boundary. It is manifested that the growth of the grain boundary has been restricted by the particle and changed with the shape of the particle.
Fig. 7c shows the distribution of the finer nano g-Al2O3 particles which is smaller than 10 nm that has never been reported before. Fig. 7d demonstrates the electron diffraction results for the selected area in Fig. 7c. In the Fig. 7e, it is showed that there is no apparent fixed orientation relationship between the alumina particles and aluminum matrix.
Fig. 7f shows the distribution of the nano g-Al2O3 particles in Al9Co2, which are below 10 nm. In view of the in-situ reaction between the Co3O4 and Al matrix, when the Co3O4 was reduced by Al that was followed by the generation of g-Al2O3 and Co element or Co containing phase, the newborn nanometer Al2O3 would adhere to the Co containing phase. It accounts for the slight difference between cobalt and oxygen elements in the Energy Dispersive Xray Detector mapping. The sizes of Co containing phase as Al9Co2 are several micrometers, which is larger than the reactant Co3O4 (30e100 nm) because the combination tendency of Al and Co is big enough to absorb sufficient Al and Co elements and generates a comparatively bigger phase. It is proved that the Co3O4 powder is nonexistent in the composite.

sections.heading: 3.5. Tensile properties
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 8, it demonstrates the dependence of ultimate tensile strength (UTS) and elongation (El) on content of g-Al2O3 particles. It reveals that the UTS and El are notably enhanced with the increase of g-Al2O3 content and arrive at the maximum when the concentration of g-Al2O3 is up to 0.6 vol%. The maximum UTS and El are 280MPa and 6.5% respectively. In comparison to the
A356 matrix, the UTS has increased by 43.6% from 195MPa to 280MPa, and El increases by 85.7% from 3.5% to 6.5%. Once the gAl2O3 content is greater than 0.6 vol%, the UTS and El will decrease simultaneously.

sections.heading: 4.1. Uniform dispersion mechanism of endogenous particle
sections.text:
The in-situ chemical reaction involved in the process can be expressed by the following formulas:
8Al þ 3Co3O4/ 4Al2O3 þ 9Co (800e900 C) (1)
DGqCo3O4 ¼ 957300þ 456:93TðJ=molÞ (2)
DGqAl2O3 ¼ 1120480þ 214:22TðJ=molÞ (3)
DGq1 ¼ 4DGqAl2O3 3DGqCo3O4 ¼ 1610020 513:91TðJ=molÞ (4)
At hyperthermia condition the gibbs free energy of reaction (1) can be expressed as:
DG1 ¼ DGq1 þ RT ln Q (5) Here Qmeans the comprehensive activity of the reaction system and the value of Q equal 1. It implies that the following equation is right:
DG1≡DG q 1 ¼ 1610020 513:91TðJ=molÞ (6)
It can be seen that the calculated gibbs free energy DG is constantly negative at random temperature. Meanwhile, the free energy is large enough to promote the reaction proceed spontaneously, rapidly and sufficiently.
According to the results in Fig. 4, the nanometer g-Al2O3 particles disperse uniformly in the composites that appears excellent in comparison to the previous studies as conglobate cluster or network-like distribution [21]. J.B. Ferguson in his research indicated that the nano-particles have three possible existing types in the matrix, they are [23]:
Type A: the distribution of nano-particles are individual or small aggregates in large grains. Due to Orowan-type strengthening the composites exhibit high strength increase.
Type B: the nano-particles locate at the grain boundaries in small grains. The increase of strength is moderate and dependent on the degree of grain refinement.
Type C: the matrix grains without refinement and the
reinforcement particles agglomerate as a large bulk in large grains. The effect of enhanced particles is equivalent to inclusion. Both the strength and elongation of the material will decrease at the same time.
The reinforced particles in this study distribute in the grain internals and at the interface of Al matrix and Si phase when the gAl2O3 volume fraction is ranged in the 0.2e0.6 vol% content. When the volume fraction exceeds 0.8 vol%, the proportion of particles distribute in the grain has been reduced, and amounts of particles aggregate as floccule or scatter at grain boundary, as shown in Fig. 9. This phenomenon is in that with the particulate proportion increase the probability of particles impact increases. When subjected to effective collisions, some small particles will aggregate and form a new bigger particle, which is beneficial to lower down the systematic interface energy by means of reducing the particulate surface areas. When the particulate radius exceeds the eighty percent of critical radius, these “bigger” particles will be pushed to the grain boundary [23]. In the 0.8 vol% g-Al2O3p/A356 composite, there are more particles distribute adjacent to the grain boundary than other samples, as shown in Fig. 9. There are many cracks in the g-Al2O3 cluster, which will lead to a sharp decline in themechanical properties of the composite.
The fact that particles are engulfed by the a-Al reveals that the interfacial wettability is passable between the particles and the matrix, especially in the process of solidification. As for the formation of the flocculi shape of aggregated g-Al2O3 particles, it comes from the following wettability reaction [25]:
3Mg(l) þ Al2O3(s) ¼ 3MgO(s) þ 2Al(l) (7)
Due to the low content of Mg and g-Al2O3, the generated amount of intermediate product MgAl2O4 phase is slight. As we know, the previous researchers focused on the in-situ reinforced particles as nano-TiB2, nano-ZrB2, submicron Al2O3, ex-situ nanoAl2O3 and so on [13]. The wettability of these in-situ nano particles and ex-situ nano particles with the Al matrix that reported was so poor that they can neither become the heterogeneous nucleation site nor be engulfed by the growing grain. For the in-situ nano-TiB2, nano-ZrB2, ex-situ nano-Al2O3, during the process of solidification, due to their low solution in aluminum liquid and poor interface wettability with matrix the particles will be pushed to the front of the Al/Si interface, that directly leads to the formation of agglomeration or net-like structure. Till to now, almost all the in-situ Al2O3 particles reported in the literatures are at sub-micron or micron scale. However, the size of these in-situ Al2O3 particles is still much larger than the critical nucleation radius. Therefore, the Al2O3 particles are easily found at Si/Al interface together with agglomeration, which is attributed to their large size. For the micron scale particle, during the process of solidification, amounts of aluminum grains are nucleated on the surface of the particles, after the grain
Fig. 9. (a) g-Al2O3, Al9(Co,Fe)2 and Al9Co2 agglomerated at grain bou
growth, the particles will be located at the grain boundary. Hence, these problems concerning uniform particles distribution can hardly be solved unless refining the particles to nanometer scale and improving the wettability between particles and matrix.
4.2. Grain refinement and modification mechanism
In this study, three kinds of microstructures have been refined, grain size, SDAS of a-Al and modified Si phase morphology.
4.2.1. Grain size refinement HereGS, GL stand for the free energy of solid and liquid phase per unit volume. The HS, HL SS, SL do the enthalpy and entropy of solid and liquid phase respectively. Lm is heat of fusion, DSm is the melting entropy of solid, DT is the degree of super-cooling and r* is the critical nucleation radius. Their relationships can be expressed and several new parameters are defined as follows.
DHP ¼ HS HL (8)
DSm ¼ SS SL ¼ Lm Tm
(9)
DGv ¼ LmTmDT (10)
DGv ¼ 43pr 3DGv þ 4pr2s (11)
r ¼ 2s DGv ¼ 2s$Tm Lm$DT
(12)
DG*het ¼ DG*hom,f ðqÞ ¼ DG*hom 2 3cosqþ cos3q
4
(13)
Tm¼885 K(612 C), Lm¼ 1.836 109J/m3, s¼121mJ/m2.
When DT is set as 1 K, 2 K and 10 K, the corresponding r* are calculated as 122.85 nm, 61.43 nm and 12.29 nm respectively. In fact, the degree of super-cooling (DT) in this study is between 1 K and 2 K，therefore the counterpart critical nucleation radius (r*) is between 122.8 nm and 61.43 nm. For the homogeneous nucleation and heterogeneous nucleation, the critical nucleation radius are the same. The nucleation energy of heterogeneous nucleation is lower than that of homogeneous nucleation, the value of heterogeneous nucleation is equal to homogeneous nucleation multiplied by f(q). The wetting angle of g-Al2O3 and aluminum liquid is greater than 90 below 900 C [43].
ndaries(0.8 vol%g-Al2O3) (b) EDS analysis of the agglomeration.
In this study the dimension of in-situ g-Al2O3 particles generated by means of oxidation-reduction reaction is about 5e100 nm, a proportion of particles can act as the heterogeneous nucleation sites. However, the interfacial wettability between the a-Al and gAl2O3 exceeds 90 . Therefore, the expected strong grain refinement effect did not happen. In aluminum matrix composites with 0.2e0.6 vol% g-Al2O3 content, the grain size changed slightly, only when the g-Al2O3 content mounted up to 0.8 vol%, the grain size reduced sharply. At the same time, the lattice constants of alumina particles are quite different from those of aluminum, as shown in Fig. 7e. It is, therefore, concluded that g-Al2O3 cannot be used as the sites of heterogeneous nucleation. Subsequently, the grain refinement mechanism can be explained as follows: when the content of g-Al2O3 is 0.2e0.6 vol%, the particles distribute in the grain, when the content exceeds 0.8 vol%, most of the particles distribute in the vicinity of the grain boundary. During the process of solidification, these g-Al2O3 nanoparticles in the composites promote the grain refinement by being pushed ahead of the solidification front to pin the grains and confined the propagating rate of the grain boundary, as shown in Fig. 7c. After solidification, the particles distributing along grain boundaries can also play a role in limiting grain growth such as in the heat treatment process.
4.2.2. Mechanism on a-Al dendritic SDAS refinement The refinement mechanism of g-Al2O3 on the SDAS of a-Al can be explained as follows: (1) The existence of particles increases the stability of the interface. (2) The low thermal conductivity of particles affects the temperature gradient of the solidification front and becomes an obstacle to rapid solidification. (3) The presence of particles has acted as a barrier to the diffusion of elements at the dendrite tip, limiting the growth of dendrites [44].
First, during the solidification process, a-Al dendrites growth will need more energy if the interface is stable and extra energy be demanded to push particles during the dendrites growth. When the particle size is very fine, the dendrite tip will be split; while when the particle size is coarse or particulate proportion is high, the radius of dendrites tip will increase and the a-Al dendrite will coarse, as shown in Figs. 2e and 3e. This theory is on the basis of the Dutta study [45].
Secondly, in the process of solidification the g-Al2O3 particles can decrease the thermal conductivity and affect the temperature gradient in the solidification front. Therefore, particles act as a barrier to the removal of the necessary heat for further solidification, which is equivalent to the formation of local super cooling. In addition, the advancing interface behind the particle will be bifurcated due to a change in the temperature gradient.
At last, the solid particles act as a barrier which can reduce the diffusion capacity of aluminum in the melt towards the tip of the growing dendrite and prevent solute diffusion away from the tip of the growing dendrite [44]. Therefore, the dendrite growth is restricted by the concentration gradient.
The SDAS in this study is finer than those reported in previous literatures concerning in-situ Al2O3 composites [22]. Because the cobalt produced by the displacement reactionwill continue to react with aluminum to form Al9Co2 particles with the properties of high melting point and high hardness. Both the distribution behavior and role playing in SDAS refinement of Al9Co2 particles are similar with g-Al2O3 during the solidification process.
4.2.3. Silicon phase modification mechanism The modified mechanism of silicon phase can be explained as element diffusion barrier mechanism. In 4.2.2, it was found that the existence of g-Al2O3 and Al9Co2 particles hindered the diffusion of aluminum and results in the dendrite refinement. The concentration of oxygen and cobalt
elements around the eutectic structure has been shown in Figs. 4a, 5e and f. For the aluminum that does not form a-Al dendrite will form eutectic structure with silicon and lead to the increase of eutectic structure proportion, as shown in Fig. 3. At the same time, the content of fine fibrous eutectic phase increases while that of flake-like eutectic silicon decreases. In the A356 alloy, the b-Al5FeSi phase tends to distribute at the tip of the flake-like eutectic silicon phase and serves as the sites of the eutectic silicon heterogeneous nucleation. In this study, due to the addition of Co, Fe will form the solid solution with Co and Al that resulting in the absence of bAl5FeSi phase, therefore, the flake-like eutectic silicon phase will not nucleate on b-Al5FeSi as reported before [46], just as shown in Fig. 10. The distribution of Fe is not at the tip of flake-like Si phase but consistent with Co element. In this case, the undercooling degree of the melt will increase and lead to the enhancement of the fine fibrous eutectic structure and the reducing of flake-like eutectic Si phase. According to the research of Sha Meng, it was concluded that Co and Fe could generate dendrite Al15(Co,Fe)3Si2 phase or fishbone Al9(Co,Fe,Ni)2 phase [46]. In this study, in the 0.6% g-Al2O3 composite the content of Fe is 0.56% and Ni is 0.04%, therefore themain kinds of Co containing phases are Al9Co2, Al9(Co, Fe)2 and Al15(Co,Fe)3Si2.
As reported, the interface wettability between b-Al5FeSi and Si phase is excellent. However, after the cobalt addition, the interface wettability between the new formed compounds or mixtures and Si phase had got worse. The Fig. 11 manifests the interface between Al9Co2 phase and Si phase. The Si phase is separated by Al9Co2 phase into several portions that the boundary can be clearly observed. The precipitation temperature of Al9Co2 phase is higher than that of Si phase, thus during the solidification process the Al9Co2 phase that was pushed to the boundary could restrict the growth of Si phase. The big bulk is Si phasewith smooth surface and the rough one is the Al9Co2 phase. Lots of tiny Al9Co2 particles distribute adjacent to the Al9Co2 phase, whose dimensions are greater than 100 nm but less 500 nm. It is inferred that the size of these Al9Co2 particles has exceeded the 80% critical radius; hence they are pushed together, where the outer surface still maintains the small Al9Co2 particulate morphology.
Eutectic Si can be modified by many elements, for example, Sr, Na, Eu, Sc and so on. But in this study the direction of Si phase twins does not conform to the impurity-induced twinning (IIT) theory model and twin plane re-entrant edge (TPRE) poison model, as shown in Fig. 12. During the growth of Si phase, cobalt had not been absorbed by Si phase. Hence cobalt is not as a specific element which can change the growth direction of Si phase.

sections.heading: 4.3. Strengthening mechanism
sections.text:
The strength improvement in nano g-Al2O3/A356 composite can be attributed to two possible micro-mechanisms: Orowan strengthening (DsOR), and dislocations strengthening(DsCTE). At lower g-Al2O3 concentrations the Orowan strengthening effect is much higher than the HallePetch strengthening. In view of microstructure, when the g-Al2O3 concentration is in the range of 0.2e0.6% the particles has been engulfed by the grains. The available mechanical properties and grain size manifest that the strength type is type A belongs to the Orowan strengthening. The cut-off point of strengthening the type change is 0.6%, less than 0.6% belongs to Orowan strengthening, and higher than 0.6% belongs to refinement strengthening. When the g-Al2O3 concentration is up to 0.8%, the UTS and El has been decreased that is due to the crake in the Al9Co2 phase, as shown in Fig. 9. In Fig. 13, it displays the fracture morphology of the A356 matrix and the composites with different g-Al2O3 content. Under the g-Al2O3 free conditions, the fracture surface of the A356 matrix are mainly
covered by cleavage plane. With the increase of particulate content, the fracture type gradually changed from cleavage fracture to ductile fracture. As shown in Fig. 12b, it is clearly observed that the fracture surfaces are composed of cleavage planes and some dimples. It indicates that materials fracture changes from brittle fracture to plastic fracture, with the particle addition. When the content of g-Al2O3 up to 0.4 vol% and 0.6 vol%, it is discovered that both the amount and the area of the cleavage planes decrease simultaneously and are replaced by the increase of dimples. The change of brittle fracture to plastic fracture is in that the refinement of eutectic silicon and a-Al dendrites increases the elongation of the composites. When the content of g-Al2O3 up to 0.8 vol%, there are
still large amount of dimples. However, the g-Al2O3 cluster are brittle phases can hardly deform will lead to the stress concentration, which is accompanied by a decrease in strength and elongation.
The contribution of refinement strengthening (Dsg) can be calculated by the Hall-Petch empirical equation, the Dsg can be expressed as [47]:
Dsg ¼ kd 1=2 (8)
where d is the mean grain size and confirmed as 10 mm and k¼ 70MPa mm1/2 is a material constant.
The g-Al2O3 nanoparticles engulfed by the grains can restrict the dislocation activity and increase in yield strength. Assuming that all the g-Al2O3 particles are spherical and distributed uniformly, the resulting DsOR can be obtained from the Orowan-Ashby equation [48,49]:
DsOR ¼ 0:13 Gb l ln r b
(14)
l ¼ dp "
1 2Vp
1 3 1 #
(15)
Where G¼ 26.2 GPa is the matrix shear modulus, b¼ 0.286 nm is the Burgers vector, n¼ 0.345 is the Poisson's ratio and l is the effective interparticle spacing, r is the mean radius of g-Al2O3 particle, Vp is the particulate content of g-Al2O3.
Due to the difference in the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) between matrix and the nano g-Al2O3 particle, high-density dislocation are generated around the nano particles in the air
cooling circumstance after solidification. The YS increases due to this effect (DsCTE) can be calculated by Refs. [48e50]: DsCTE ¼ hGb ffiffiffi r p (16)
r ¼ 12 Da,DT,Vp bD 1 Vp
(17) where Da is the difference in CTE between the matrix (23.6 10 6 K 1) and the reinforcing particles (6.78 10 6 K 1).DT is the difference between the processing and test temperature. In this work, the temperatures of liquid aluminum alloy (610 C) and the preheated mold (200 C) are taken as the processing temperature and the test temperature, respectively. h¼ 1 is a constant.
The result of 0.6% Al2O3 content composite theoretical calculation is Dsg¼ 5.78MPa, DsOR¼ 17.9MPa, DsCTE¼ 34.2MPa. The YS of A356 free of particle and the 0.6% content composite are 135MPa and 205Mpa respectively. The theoretical calculation is a little lower than the measure result. It is inferred that the reduced cobalt result in the strengthen effect. There are a little proportion of oxide film in the composites, although protective measures had been taken during themelting process. The plane presents in the fracture surface of the composite reveals the existence of oxide film, as shown in Fig. 12f, which can result a remarkable decrease of the UTS about 10e20Mpa.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present work, the in-situ g-Al2O3 particles reinforced A356 aluminum matrix composites have been fabricated in the A356 aluminum alloy and cobalt (II, III) oxide components by means of direct melt reaction method. The effect of volume fraction of in-situ g-Al2O3 particles and cobalt element on the microstructure andmechanical properties of A356 alloy was studied. Based on the results obtained, the main conclusions can be summarized as follows:
(1) The g-Al2O3 particles can be engulfed by the grain when the particulate content is lower than 0.6 vol%. However, a further increase in the amount of g-Al2O3 particles up to 0.8 vol% leads to the particles be pushed to the grain boundaries. (2) The g-Al2O3 particles can significantly refine the a-Al dendrites. The optimum g-Al2O3 content is 0.6 vol%, on this condition the secondary dendrite arm space (SDAS) is 13e14 mm. (3) The cobalt produced by the reduction reaction can modify the Si phase. Cobalt reduces the nucleation site of the preeutectic silicon by forming Al9(Co,Fe)2 and Al15(Co,Fe)3Si2 compounds with iron and increases the volume of eutectic silicon. (4) Due to the refinement of a-Al dendrites and modification on eutectic Si crystals, the ultimate tensile strength and elongation are significantly improved for 0.6 vol% g-Al2O3 sample, in which the ultimate tensile strength and elongation have been enhanced by 43.6% and 85.7% to 280MPa and 6.5%, respectively.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, the nanometer in-situ g-Al2O3 particles reinforced aluminum matrix composites was successfully fabricated by the A356 aluminum alloy and Co3O4 powder at 850 C by means of in-situ reaction in the high temperature melt. The effects of g-Al2O3 particle and cobalt element on the microstructure and properties of the composites were investigated in detail. The endogenous g-Al2O3 and cobalt could modify the coarse plate like eutectic Si into fine fibrous like and refine the second dendrite arm spacing (SDAS) of the grains simultaneously. When the content of cobalt was lower than 0.57% and content of g-Al2O3particles was lower than 0.6 vol%, the particles distributed uniformly in the grain, however, when the particulate amount was up to 0.8 vol%, the particles would distribute at the grains boundaries or form as a rodlike phase. The grain size was sharply refined to 200 mm when the particulate content was 0.8 vol%. It was found that the ultimate tensile strength (UTS), elongation of the 0.6 vol% g-Al2O3/A356 composites had arrived at the maximum that had enhanced by 43.6% and 85.7% in comparison to the matrix respectively, which were attributed to the homogeneous distribution of the nanoparticles, the refinement of the SDAS of the a-Al grains and the modification of the eutectic Si
